skill.name: line-limit
skill.description: Enforce file line count limits (200 recommended, 300 max) for CODE IMPLEMENTATION files only. Use this when reviewing code, creating files, or when files exceed line limits and need modularization.
skill.summary: Enforce file line count limits (200 recommended, 300 max) for CODE IMPLEMENTATION files only. Use th...
skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown files describing line limit enforcement and modularization patterns. No security risks detected.

content.value_statement: Long code files are hard to maintain and understand. This skill automatically checks line counts and helps you split oversized files into manageable, well-organized modules.
actual_capabilities: Automatically counts lines in code files
Suggests modularization for files over 300 lines
limitations: Only applies to code implementation files
Excludes documentation, config, and test fixtures

use_cases.title: Code Review Quality Checks
use_cases.description: Automatically flag oversized files during code reviews and suggest proper modularization strategies.

use_cases.title: Enforce Project Standards
use_cases.description: Maintain consistent file size limits across your codebase to improve readability and maintainability.

use_cases.title: Learn Modularization Patterns
use_cases.description: Get guided assistance on how to properly structure and organize large code files.

prompt_templates.title: Basic File Check
prompt_templates.scenario: Check if a file needs splitting
prompt_templates.prompt: Check the line count of src/components/Dashboard.tsx and tell me if it needs modularization

prompt_templates.title: Review with Limits
prompt_templates.scenario: Code review with line limit check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code file and check if it exceeds the recommended line limits: src/utils/helpers.js

prompt_templates.title: Modularize Request
prompt_templates.prompt: This file is too long at 450 lines. Please modularize src/services/api.ts following best practices

prompt_templates.title: New File Creation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new React component but keep it under 200 lines by splitting into logical sub-components

output_examples.input: Check src/components/UserProfile.tsx for line limit violations

best_practices: Keep files under 200 lines for optimal readability
Group related functionality together when splitting
Use consistent naming conventions across split files
anti_patterns: Splitting files purely to meet line limits without logical separation
Creating circular dependencies between split modules
Ignoring cohesion just to reduce line count

faq.question: Which files are exempt from line limits?
faq.answer: Documentation (.md), config files, test fixtures, Jupyter notebooks, CSS files, and auto-generated files are exempt.

faq.question: What happens at exactly 300 lines?
faq.answer: 300 lines triggers a warning. Files with 301+ lines require mandatory modularization.

faq.question: Can I customize the line limits?
faq.answer: Currently fixed at 200 (recommended) and 300 (maximum) lines based on best practices.

faq.question: Will this modify my code automatically?
faq.answer: No, the skill suggests changes but requires your approval before any refactoring.

faq.question: How does it handle existing import statements?
faq.answer: The skill preserves and properly re-exports all imports when splitting files.

faq.question: Is this compatible with all programming languages?
faq.answer: Supports major languages: JavaScript, TypeScript, Python, Go, Rust, Java, C/C++ and more.
